name: Kepler-399
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-399 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-399 is a star with 0.58 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.68 times its radius. It is located 4442.83 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-399 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-399 b

Kepler-399 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 14.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-399.

The mass of Kepler-399 b is 0.88 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-399 b is 0.96 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-399 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-399 c

Kepler-399 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 26.68 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-399.

The mass of Kepler-399 c is 2.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-399 c is 1.43 that of Earth. At 2.29 Earth masses, Kepler-399 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-399 d

Kepler-399 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.26 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 58.03 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-399.

The mass of Kepler-399 d is 4.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-399 d is 1.89 that of Earth. At 4.46 Earth masses, Kepler-399 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.261 astronomical units, and a mass of 4.46 Earth masses, Kepler-399 d could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-399, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
